page.title: 07The railway today
page.content: The writer often made the journey from Newcastle to Bedford via Sandy in the late 1950's and early 1960's and sometimes spent an hour waiting for a connection. The stations shared one island platform and also had one facing platform each. After closure of the Bedford line, the island platform was eventually demolished and the main lines widened to four tracks as they already were both north and south of Sandy station. The new up platform (for London) was built for the easternmost tracks. The L.N.W.R. goods yard is used for non railway traffic today but a siding still exists on the site of the G.N.R. yard, serving U.K.F. Fertiliser depot.
